dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Bernie Sanders and Pramila Jayapal just introduced a bill to make college tuition free for millions of Americans.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Bernie Sanders and Pramila Jayapal just introduced a bill to make college tuition free for millions of Americans.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) on Wednesday introduced legislation to make college tuition free for millions of Americans, paid for by a new tax on Wall Street trades.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, and they're funding it with a new tax on stock and bond trades—like 0.5% on stocks, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, and they're funding it with a new tax on stock and bond trades-like zero point five percent on stocks, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The federal investments in education and tuition would be paid for with a separate bill called the Tax on Wall Street Speculation Act, which would levy a new tax of 0.5% on stock trades, a 0.1% fee on bond trades and a 0.005% fee on derivatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it would cover community college, trade schools, and public four-year colleges for families making under $130,000 a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it would cover community college, trade schools, and public four-year colleges for families making under one hundred thirty thousand dollars a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The College for All Plan would make community college and trade school tuition free for everyone, and it would eliminate tuition at public four-year colleges and universities for students from families earning less than $125,000 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That income cap is pretty significant—it'd help a ton of middle-class families, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That income cap is pretty significant-it'd help a ton of middle-class families, honestly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they're also targeting support for HBCUs and minority-serving institutions, which is huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're also targeting support for HBCUs and minority-serving institutions, which is huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It would also make tuition free at private Historically Black Colleges and Universities and other minority-serving institutions for students from families in that income bracket.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the funding mechanism… that Wall Street speculation tax is estimated to raise, what, $2.3 trillion over a decade?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the funding mechanism... that Wall Street speculation tax is estimated to raise, what, two point three dollars trillion over a decade?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: $2.4 trillion. Thats how much the new tax on Wall Street transactions could raise over the next decade, according to a summary of the legislation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, though some analysts think that number might be optimistic. The Tax Policy Center projected way less back in 2016.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, though some analysts think that number might be optimistic. The Tax Policy Center projected way less back in twenty sixteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the Tax Policy Center analyzed Sanders campaign proposal for a financial transaction tax (a plan he said would raise $3 trillion over a decade), it concluded that the proposal would only generate about $400 billion in revenue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, uh, critics are already saying it could hurt everyday investors saving for retirement or college.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, uh, critics are already saying it could hurt everyday investors saving for retirement or college.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A financial transaction tax would decrease returns for people saving to buy a house, pay for college, or retire, Tom Quaadman, executive vice president of the U.S. Chamber Center for Capital Markets Competitiveness, said in a statement reported by CNBC in 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Tom Quaadman from the Chamber of Commerce called it out for potentially making capital more expensive for businesses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Tom Quaadman from the Chamber of Commerce called it out for potentially making capital more expensive for businesses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It would also make it more expensive for businesses to raise the capital they need to start, expand, and create jobs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But Jayapal's argument is that working families shouldn't have to take on crushing debt just to get an education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Jayapal's argument is that working families shouldn't have to take on crushing debt just to get an education.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While President Biden can and should immediately cancel student debt for millions of borrowers, Congress must ensure that working families never have to take out these crushing loans to receive a higher education in the first place, Jayapal said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's definitely reigniting the debate about who should pay for higher education in this country.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's definitely reigniting the debate about who should pay for higher education in this country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And this isn't even the first time Sanders has pushed this—he was talking about a financial transaction tax back in 2016.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And this isn't even the first time Sanders has pushed this-he was talking about a financial transaction tax back in twenty sixteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This isnt the first time Sanders has pushed for a financial transaction taxhe floated the idea during his presidential campaign in 2016 and introduced legislation containing the tax in 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder if the political climate is any different now for something like this to gain traction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder if the political climate is any different now for something like this to gain traction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, with student debt cancellation already on the table, it feels like the conversation is shifting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, with student debt cancellation already on the table, it feels like the conversation is shifting.

artist_script:
Tax on Wall Street trades to fund free college tuition, proposed by Bernie Sanders and Pramila Jayapal.
HostA: Bernie Sanders and Pramila Jayapal just introduced a bill to make college tuition free for millions of Americans.
HostB: Oh yeah, and they’re funding it with a new tax on stock and bond trades—like 0.5% on stocks, right?
HostA: Exactly. And it would cover community college, trade schools, and public four-year colleges for families making under $130,000 a year.
HostB: That income cap is pretty significant—it’d help a ton of middle-class families, honestly.
HostA: And they’re also targeting support for HBCUs and minority-serving institutions, which is huge.
HostB: But the funding mechanism… that Wall Street speculation tax is estimated to raise, what, $2.3 trillion over a decade?
HostA: Yeah, though some analysts think that number might be optimistic. The Tax Policy Center projected way less back in 2016.
HostB: Right, uh, critics are already saying it could hurt everyday investors saving for retirement or college.
HostA: Tom Quaadman from the Chamber of Commerce called it out for potentially making capital more expensive for businesses.
HostB: But Jayapal’s argument is that working families shouldn’t have to take on crushing debt just to get an education.
HostA: It’s definitely reigniting the debate about who should pay for higher education in this country.
HostB: And this isn’t even the first time Sanders has pushed this—he was talking about a financial transaction tax back in 2016.
HostA: Makes you wonder if the political climate is any different now for something like this to gain traction.
HostB: I mean, with student debt cancellation already on the table, it feels like the conversation is shifting.
